hints_html:
There is a formula for the inverse of a \(2\times{}2\) matrix in the form

\(A=\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\)

which is

\[\begin{aligned} A^{-1}=\frac{1}{\text{det}(A)}\begin{bmatrix} d & -b\\ -c & a \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

If you can compute the determinant of A then the inverse can be written down immediately.

question: A 07
sols_html:
We see from the hint that the formula for an inverse of \(2\times{2}\) matrices of the form

\[\begin{aligned} A= \begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

is

\[\begin{aligned} A^{-1}=\frac{1}{\text{det}(A)}\begin{bmatrix} d & -b\\ -c & a \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

In this example we have

\[\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2\\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}\text{det}(A)=1-2=-1.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we have that

\[\begin{aligned} A^{-1}=-1 \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -2\\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 2\\ 1 & -1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]
